block.p: To the Editor:
Re ''Pelosi's Delegation Presses Syrian Leader on Militants'' (news article, April 5):
To the Editor:
Re ''Pelosi's Delegation Presses Syrian Leader on Militants'' (news article, April 5):
How many people, how many commissions and how many experts in international relations have to speak out before the Bush administration changes its view on diplomacy?
Even former Secretary of State James A. Baker III has stated that we need to talk to Iran and Syria, but the administration still refuses.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has the right idea. We need to maintain a dialogue even with those we may see as our enemies or ''foes.''

As John F. Kennedy once said, ''To those nations who would make themselves our adversary, we offer not a pledge but a request: that both sides begin anew the quest for peace, before the dark powers of destruction unleashed by science engulf all humanity in planned or accidental self-destruction.''
President Bush could learn a lesson by using his history degree.
Cris Nolan Mundelein, Ill., April 5, 2007
To the Editor:
Re ''Pelosi, Warmly Greeted in Syria, Is Criticized by White House'' (news article, April 4):
Intelligence and reason are finally finding their way to the Middle East, and the feckless Bush administration is seeking to vilify the effort.
Those are my headlines.
Jim Hoover Huntington Beach, Calif. April 5, 2007
To the Editor:
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has no business conducting foreign relations policy in Syria. Syria is a state sponsor of terrorism. Its government undermines the interests of the United States.
Ms. Pelosi and those who accompanied her on this ill-conceived visit should be ridiculed publicly for their behavior.
These brazen acts by supposedly responsible lawmakers are a travesty and undercut both our government and our people. The American people should not tolerate this kind of behavior.
Bob Jack North Las Vegas, Nev., April 5, 2007
